Dear Sheffield City Council,
Given Paul Brooke’s request regarding the apology for SCC misleading a court with documents provided.
And the finding in the Lowcock report the council submitted misleading documents to the court.
Can the council confirm or deny if they hold records where they have investigated other instances of where the local authority may have provided other misleading/fabricated/erroneous documents in legal proceedings. This time period will be either or while Steve Eccleston was head of legal and Gillian Duckworth was head of governance.
If records are held can the council provide a summary of the records they retain, volume and nature.
Yours faithfully,
Marcus Combie

Dear Marcus Combie,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Lowcock findings
which we received on 09/12/2023.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
We apologise for missing the legal deadline for our response.
Your request refers to a period where  Steve Eccleston was ‘head of legal’
and Gillian Duckworth was ‘head of governance’.  For clarity, Steve
Eccleston has never held that position, his role with Sheffield City
Council was latterly Assistant Director Legal and Governance.  Gillian
Duckworth was Director of Legal and Governance from 2014.  We have
therefore assumed that 2014 onwards is the relevant period for your
request, please let us know if this is not correct.
In your request you state that the Lowcock Inquiry ‘found the Council
submitted misleading documents to the court’.  In fact the Inquiry noted
that the document in question was submitted by the other party to the
proceedings and not by the Council.  However, it is also clear that the
Council made significant errors in relation to the document and we have
accepted the Inquiry findings in full on this point, including through
submitting an apology to the courts.
Turning to your request.  I am afraid, we do not know whether we hold
information which might fall into the category you have identified. We are
not aware of any such investigations. The relevant period is over 10 years
and across the Council we have been involved in many cases involving the
courts and the task of examining each file to look for the requested
information would exceed the cost of compliance under section 12(2) of the
Act. The cost limit of £450 is equivalent to 18 hours of officer time
specified in the [1]Freedom of Information and Data Protection
(Appropriate Limit and Fees) Regulations 2004 (SI 2004 No. 3244).
Our case work is voluminous and extensive across a range of public
services. It would not be possible to undertake an assessment as to
whether any information was improperly submitted in legal proceedings
within the time frame prescribed by the Act.
Under section 16 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000, we have a duty to
provide advice and assistance to requesters. If you would like to narrow
down the focus of your request, we would be happy to process your revised
request as a new request for information under the Freedom of Information
Act 2000. You might consider whether you want to know if we have had any
complaints for a specified period about our litigation to our corporate
complaints process.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [2]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[3]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council

Sheffield, S1 1UJ
